In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain why different equations can represent the same sequence.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.17.1: Repeated Addition Is Multiplication
    • In this activity, you looked at different ways to represent repeated addition with multiplication and exponents.
  • 4.17.2: Define a Sequence by the nth Term
    • In this activity, you learned how to represent sequences with definitions that aren’t recursive.
    • 4.17.2: Self Check 
  • 4.17.3: Identify a Domain for a Function
    • In this activity, you explored two different ways to write the geometric sequence formed by the pattern of the Sierpinski triangle.
    • 4.17.3: Self Check 
  • 4.17.4: Interchanging Between Formulas
    • In this activity, you learned that arithmetic and geometric sequences can be written using the recursive definition and the nth term. It is possible to use them interchangeably.
    • 4.17.4: Self Check
  • 4.17.5: Different Types of Equations
    • In this activity, you looked at how the same arithmetic sequence was represented recursively and with the nth term.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.17.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
